comment_text.mn136:2.2: This is the only time we meet Potaliputta. His name suggests he hails from the capital of Assaka, variously spelled Potali or Potana (DN 19:36.4). | As for Samiddhi, see note on MN 133:1.3.
comment_text.mn136:2.8: There is indeed no such statement in the suttas.
comment_text.mn136:2.9: This is the cessation of perception and feelings.
comment_text.mn136:2.14: It is this answer of Samiddhi’s that is criticized below.
comment_text.mn136:6.5: There are several monks named Udāyī and it is not easy to distinguish them. One of then was known for his stupidity (AN 6.29:3.3). | Ummagga is from ummujjati, just below, “uprising, emergence”.
comment_text.mn136:6.15: Text here reads vibhajantassa, which appears ungrammatical. This phrase is shared with AN 6.62:5.8, which is also a case where a junior monk has made a silly statement. There the Pali has vibhajissāmi (“I will explain”). The commentary does not explicitly comment on this phrase, but it does say that the Buddha thought, “I will make it clear for the mendicant Saṅgha” (bhikkhusaṅghassa pākaṭaṁ karissāmīti), which implies that it was reading the future tense. Compare the use of future tense in the stock phrase, “Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak” (MN 138:2.2).
comment_text.mn136:9.1: Meditation is described in the same way at DN 1:1.31.1, which is also concerned with those who draw inaccurate inferences from deep meditation.
comment_text.mn136:9.4: The use of kira (“seems”) conveys an appropriate degree of caution when framing a hypothesis. But as we shall see, the theorist does not maintain this.
comment_text.mn136:9.5: Having framed their hypothesis, the theorist presents their supporting observations.
comment_text.mn136:9.7: Now the theorist draws their inference, committing two logical fallacies. One is the fallacy of hasty generalization: the fact that some people who do bad deeds go to hell does not imply that all people who do bad deeds go to hell. The second is the post hoc fallacy: the fact that the bad deed preceded rebirth in hell does not imply that the bad deed caused rebirth in hell. The Buddha avoids the fallacy of hasty generalization by surveying a much larger, statistically significant scope, said to be ninety-one eons (MN 71:14.2). And he avoids the post hoc fallacy by flipping the causal arrow: if the presence of kamma leads to rebirth, then the absence of kamma should lead to the ending of rebirth. By practicing to realize the ending of kamma he confirmed this for himself.
comment_text.mn136:9.8: Leaving behind caution and going beyond observation, the theorist now asserts that the results of their reasoning are the truth. | Here words from the root √ñā are used for both right and wrong ideas. Normally I translate √ñā as “knowledge”, but in English one cannot “know” something false. One might believe that it is nighttime when it is in fact the day, but one cannot know this. Usually √ñā does have the positive sense of “true knowledge”, but when dealing with errant theorizers we also find it used for “false knowledge”, in which case I use “notion” (eg. Snp 4.13:17.2).
comment_text.mn136:9.9: Contemplatives sometimes deprecate logic as inferior to meditative insight. By not exercising the critical skills to evaluate and improve their reasoning, they become especially prone to using poor logic. The brilliance of meditative experiences can be overwhelming and it is easy to be convinced of the truth of one’s inferences, without even recognizing them as inferences. sutta passages such as this show that the interpretation of meditative experiences must be tempered with clear logic.
comment_text.mn136:17.2: The logic of this passage seems to be: “When a good result follows a bad deed, or bad follows good, then they must have done some other fitting deed at another time; and even if a bad result follows a bad deed, or good follows good, it is still possible that the result was caused by some other fitting deed.” But the phrasing of the Pali does not quite say this. I suspect that some nuance has been lost, perhaps due to over-zealous standardization. | For deathbed kamma see MN 97:38.7 and note.

root_text.mn136:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
root_text.mn136:2.1: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā samiddhi araññakuṭikāyaṁ viharati.
root_text.mn136:2.2: Atha kho potaliputto paribbājako jaṅghāvihāraṁ anucaṅkamamāno anuvicaramāno yenāyasmā samiddhi tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā samiddhinā saddhiṁ sammodi.
root_text.mn136:2.3: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho potaliputto paribbājako āyasmantaṁ samiddhiṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn136:2.4: “sammukhā metaṁ, āvuso samiddhi, samaṇassa gotamassa sutaṁ, sammukhā paṭiggahitaṁ:
root_text.mn136:2.6: Atthi ca sā samāpatti yaṁ samāpattiṁ samāpanno na kiñci vediyatī”ti?
root_text.mn136:2.7: “Mā hevaṁ, āvuso potaliputta, avaca; mā hevaṁ, āvuso potaliputta, avaca; mā bhagavantaṁ abbhācikkhi. Na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhakkhānaṁ. Na hi bhagavā evaṁ vadeyya:
root_text.mn136:2.9: ‘Atthi ca kho sā, āvuso, samāpatti yaṁ samāpattiṁ samāpanno na kiñci vediyatī’”ti.
root_text.mn136:2.12: “Ettha dāni mayaṁ there bhikkhū kiṁ vakkhāma, yatra hi nāma evaṁnavo bhikkhu satthāraṁ parirakkhitabbaṁ maññissati.
root_text.mn136:2.13: Sañcetanikaṁ, āvuso samiddhi, kammaṁ katvā kāyena vācāya manasā kiṁ so vediyatī”ti?
root_text.mn136:2.14: “Sañcetanikaṁ, āvuso potaliputta, kammaṁ katvā kāyena vācāya manasā dukkhaṁ so vediyatī”ti.
root_text.mn136:2.15: Atha kho potaliputto paribbājako āyasmato samiddhissa bhāsitaṁ neva abhinandi nappaṭikkosi;
root_text.mn136:3.1: Atha kho āyasmā samiddhi acirapakkante potaliputte paribbājake yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṁ sammodi.
root_text.mn136:3.2: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.mn136:3.3: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā samiddhi yāvatako ahosi potaliputtena paribbājakena saddhiṁ kathāsallāpo taṁ sabbaṁ āyasmato ānandassa ārocesi.
root_text.mn136:3.4: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā ānando āyasmantaṁ samiddhiṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn136:3.5: “atthi kho idaṁ, āvuso samiddhi, kathāpābhataṁ bhagavantaṁ dassanāya.
root_text.mn136:3.6: Āyāmāvuso samiddhi, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamissāma; upasaṅkamitvā etamatthaṁ bhagavato ārocessāma.
root_text.mn136:3.7: Yathā no bhagavā byākarissati tathā naṁ dhāressāmā”ti.
root_text.mn136:3.8: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā samiddhi āyasmato ānandassa paccassosi.
root_text.mn136:4.1: Atha kho āyasmā ca ānando āyasmā ca samiddhi yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.
root_text.mn136:4.2: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando yāvatako ahosi āyasmato samiddhissa potaliputtena paribbājakena saddhiṁ kathāsallāpo taṁ sabbaṁ bhagavato ārocesi.
root_text.mn136:5.1: Evaṁ vutte, bhagavā āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn136:5.2: “dassanampi kho ahaṁ, ānanda, potaliputtassa paribbājakassa nābhijānāmi, kuto panevarūpaṁ kathāsallāpaṁ?
root_text.mn136:5.3: Iminā ca, ānanda, samiddhinā moghapurisena potaliputtassa paribbājakassa vibhajjabyākaraṇīyo pañho ekaṁsena byākato”ti.
root_text.mn136:6.1: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā udāyī bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn136:6.2: “sace pana, bhante, āyasmatā samiddhinā idaṁ sandhāya bhāsitaṁ—
root_text.mn136:6.4: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.mn136:6.5: “passasi no tvaṁ, ānanda, imassa udāyissa moghapurisassa ummaṅgaṁ?
root_text.mn136:6.8: Ādiṁyeva, ānanda, potaliputtena paribbājakena tisso vedanā pucchitā.
root_text.mn136:6.9: Sacāyaṁ, ānanda, samiddhi moghapuriso potaliputtassa paribbājakassa evaṁ puṭṭho evaṁ byākareyya:
root_text.mn136:6.10: ‘sañcetanikaṁ, āvuso potaliputta, kammaṁ katvā kāyena vācāya manasā sukhavedanīyaṁ sukhaṁ so vedayati;
root_text.mn136:6.11: sañcetanikaṁ, āvuso potaliputta, kammaṁ katvā kāyena vācāya manasā dukkhavedanīyaṁ dukkhaṁ so vedayati;
root_text.mn136:6.12: sañcetanikaṁ, āvuso potaliputta, kammaṁ katvā kāyena vācāya manasā adukkhamasukhavedanīyaṁ adukkhamasukhaṁ so vedayatī’ti.
root_text.mn136:6.13: Evaṁ byākaramāno kho, ānanda, samiddhi moghapuriso potaliputtassa paribbājakassa sammā byākaramāno byākareyya.
root_text.mn136:6.14: Api ca, ānanda, ke ca aññatitthiyā paribbājakā bālā abyattā ke ca tathāgatassa mahākammavibhaṅgaṁ jānissanti?
root_text.mn136:6.15: Sace tumhe, ānanda, suṇeyyātha tathāgatassa mahākammavibhaṅgaṁ vibhajantassā”ti.

root_text.mn136:7.3: “Tena hānanda, suṇāhi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
root_text.mn136:7.4: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

root_text.mn136:15.2: ‘atthi kira, bho, kalyāṇāni kammāni, atthi sucaritassa vipāko’ti idamassa anujānāmi;
root_text.mn136:15.4: ‘amāhaṁ puggalaṁ addasaṁ—idha pāṇātipātā paṭivirataṁ adinnādānā paṭivirataṁ …pe… sammādiṭṭhiṁ, kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā passāmi sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannan’ti idampissa anujānāmi;
root_text.mn136:15.6: ‘yo kira, bho, pāṇātipātā paṭivirato adinnādānā paṭivirato …pe… sammādiṭṭhi, sabbo so kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjatī’ti idamassa nānujānāmi;
root_text.mn136:15.8: ‘ye evaṁ jānanti te sammā jānanti; ye aññathā jānanti, micchā tesaṁ ñāṇan’ti idampissa nānujānāmi;
root_text.mn136:15.9: yampi so yadeva tassa sāmaṁ ñātaṁ sāmaṁ diṭṭhaṁ sāmaṁ viditaṁ tadeva tattha thāmasā parāmāsā abhinivissa voharati: ‘idameva saccaṁ, moghamaññan’ti idampissa nānujānāmi.
root_text.mn136:15.11: Aññathā hi, ānanda, tathāgatassa mahākammavibhaṅge ñāṇaṁ hoti.

root_text.mn136:17.1: Tatrānanda, yvāyaṁ puggalo idha pāṇātipātī adinnādāyī …pe… micchādiṭṭhi, kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjati,
root_text.mn136:17.2: pubbe vāssa taṁ kataṁ hoti pāpakammaṁ dukkhavedanīyaṁ, pacchā vāssa taṁ kataṁ hoti pāpakammaṁ dukkhavedanīyaṁ, maraṇakāle vāssa hoti micchādiṭṭhi samattā samādinnā.

root_text.mn136:19.3: Tena so kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjati.

root_text.mn136:20.1: Tatrānanda, yvāyaṁ puggalo idha pāṇātipātā paṭivirato adinnādānā paṭivirato …pe… sammādiṭṭhi, kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjati,
root_text.mn136:20.2: pubbe vāssa taṁ kataṁ hoti pāpakammaṁ dukkhavedanīyaṁ, pacchā vāssa taṁ kataṁ hoti pāpakammaṁ dukkhavedanīyaṁ, maraṇakāle vāssa hoti micchādiṭṭhi samattā samādinnā.
root_text.mn136:20.3: Tena so kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjati.

root_text.mn136:21.1: Iti kho, ānanda, atthi kammaṁ abhabbaṁ abhabbābhāsaṁ, atthi kammaṁ abhabbaṁ bhabbābhāsaṁ, atthi kammaṁ bhabbañceva bhabbābhāsañca, atthi kammaṁ bhabbaṁ abhabbābhāsan”ti.
root_text.mn136:21.3: Attamano āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.mn136:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
translation_text.mn136:2.1: Now at that time Venerable Samiddhi was staying in a wilderness hut.
translation_text.mn136:2.2: Then as the wanderer Potaliputta was going for a walk he came up to Venerable Samiddhi and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.mn136:2.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to him:
translation_text.mn136:2.4: “Reverend Samiddhi, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the ascetic Gotama:
translation_text.mn136:2.5: ‘Deeds by way of body and speech are done in vain. Only mental deeds are real.’
translation_text.mn136:2.6: And: ‘There is such an attainment where the one who enters it does not feel anything at all.’”
translation_text.mn136:2.7: “Don’t say that, Reverend Potaliputta, don’t say that! Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say this:
translation_text.mn136:2.8: ‘Deeds by way of body and speech are done in vain. Only mental deeds are real.’
translation_text.mn136:2.9: But, reverend, there is such an attainment where the one who enters it does not feel anything at all.”
translation_text.mn136:2.10: “Reverend Samiddhi, how long has it been since you went forth?”
translation_text.mn136:2.12: “Well now, what are we to say to the senior mendicants, when even such a junior mendicant imagines their Teacher needs defending?
translation_text.mn136:2.13: After doing an intentional deed by way of body, speech, or mind, reverend, what does one feel?”
translation_text.mn136:2.14: “After doing an intentional deed by way of body, speech, or mind, reverend, one feels suffering.”
translation_text.mn136:2.15: Then, neither approving nor rejecting Samiddhi’s statement, Potaliputta
translation_text.mn136:2.16: got up from his seat and left.
translation_text.mn136:3.1: Soon after he had left, Venerable Samiddhi went to Venerable Ānanda, and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.mn136:3.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
translation_text.mn136:3.3: and informed Ānanda of all they had discussed.
translation_text.mn136:3.4: When he had spoken, Ānanda said to him,
translation_text.mn136:3.5: “Reverend Samiddhi, we should see the Buddha about this matter.
translation_text.mn136:3.6: Come, let’s go to the Buddha and inform him about this.
translation_text.mn136:3.7: As he answers, so we’ll remember it.”
translation_text.mn136:4.1: Then Ānanda and Samiddhi went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side,
translation_text.mn136:4.2: and told him what had happened.
translation_text.mn136:5.1: When they had spoken, the Buddha said to Ānanda,
translation_text.mn136:5.2: “I don’t recall even seeing the wanderer Potaliputta, Ānanda, so how could we have had such a discussion?
translation_text.mn136:5.3: The wanderer Potaliputta’s question should have been answered after analyzing it, but this futile man answered categorically.”
translation_text.mn136:6.1: When he said this, Venerable Udāyī said to him,
translation_text.mn136:6.2: “But perhaps, sir, Venerable Samiddhi spoke in reference to the statement:
translation_text.mn136:6.4: But the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda,
translation_text.mn136:6.5: “See what this futile man Udāyī comes up with?
translation_text.mn136:6.7: he was coming up with something irrational.
translation_text.mn136:6.8: Right from the start Potaliputta asked about the three feelings.
translation_text.mn136:6.9: Suppose the futile man Samiddhi had answered the wanderer Potaliputta’s question like this:
translation_text.mn136:6.10: ‘After doing an intentional deed to be experienced as pleasant by way of body, speech, or mind, one feels pleasure.
translation_text.mn136:6.11: After doing an intentional deed to be experienced as painful by way of body, speech, or mind, one feels pain.
translation_text.mn136:6.12: After doing an intentional deed to be experienced as neutral by way of body, speech, or mind, one feels neutral.’
translation_text.mn136:6.13: Answering in this way, Samiddhi would have rightly answered Potaliputta.
translation_text.mn136:6.14: Still, who are those foolish and incompetent wanderers of other religions to understand the Realized One’s great analysis of deeds?
translation_text.mn136:6.15: If you would all listen, Ānanda, I will explain the Realized One’s great analysis of deeds.”
translation_text.mn136:7.1: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!
translation_text.mn136:7.2: Let the Buddha explain the great analysis of deeds. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
translation_text.mn136:7.3: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn136:8.1: “Ānanda, these four individuals are found in the world.
translation_text.mn136:8.3: It’s when an individual here kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re covetous, malicious, and have wrong view.
translation_text.mn136:8.4: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.mn136:8.5: But some other individual here kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re covetous, malicious, and have wrong view.
translation_text.mn136:8.6: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn136:8.7: But some other individual here refrains from killing living creatures, stealing, committing sexual misconduct, or using speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, and have right view.
translation_text.mn136:8.8: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn136:8.9: But some other individual here refrains from killing living creatures, stealing, committing sexual misconduct, or using speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, and have right view.
translation_text.mn136:8.10: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.mn136:9.1: Now, some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that it gives rise to clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman. With that clairvoyance they see that individual
translation_text.mn136:9.2: here who killed living creatures, stole, and committed sexual misconduct; who used speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; and who was covetous, malicious, and had wrong view. And they see that, when their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.mn136:9.4: ‘It seems, worthy sir, that there is such a thing as bad deeds, and the result of bad conduct.
translation_text.mn136:9.5: For I saw an individual here who killed living creatures … and had wrong view. And when their body broke up, after death, they were reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.’
translation_text.mn136:9.7: ‘It seems that everyone who kills living creatures … and has wrong view is reborn in hell.
translation_text.mn136:9.8: Those whose notion is this have the right notion. Those whose notion is otherwise have a wrong notion.’
translation_text.mn136:9.9: And so they obstinately stick to what they have known, seen, and understood for themselves, insisting that: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’
translation_text.mn136:10.1: But some other ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that it gives rise to clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman. With that clairvoyance they see that individual
translation_text.mn136:10.2: here who killed living creatures … and had wrong view. And they see that they are reborn in a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn136:10.4: ‘It seems that there is no such thing as bad deeds, and the result of bad conduct.
translation_text.mn136:10.5: For I have seen an individual here who killed living creatures … and had wrong view. And I saw that they were reborn in a heavenly realm.’
translation_text.mn136:10.7: ‘It seems that everyone who kills living creatures … and has wrong view is reborn in a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn136:10.8: Those whose notion is this have the right notion. Those whose notion is otherwise have a wrong notion.’
translation_text.mn136:10.9: And so they obstinately stick to what they have known, seen, and understood for themselves, insisting that: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’
translation_text.mn136:11.1: Take some ascetic or brahmin who with clairvoyance sees an individual
translation_text.mn136:11.2: here who refrained from killing living creatures … and had right view. And they see that they are reborn in a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn136:11.4: ‘It seems that there is such a thing as good deeds, and the result of good conduct.
translation_text.mn136:11.5: For I have seen an individual here who refrained from killing living creatures … and had right view. And I saw that they were reborn in a heavenly realm.’
translation_text.mn136:11.7: ‘It seems that everyone who refrains from killing living creatures … and has right view is reborn in a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn136:11.8: Those whose notion is this have the right notion. Those whose notion is otherwise have a wrong notion.’
translation_text.mn136:11.9: And so they obstinately stick to what they have known, seen, and understood for themselves, insisting that: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’
translation_text.mn136:12.1: Take some ascetic or brahmin who with clairvoyance sees an individual here who refrained from killing living creatures … and had right view. And they see that they are reborn in hell.
translation_text.mn136:12.3: ‘It seems that there is no such thing as good deeds, and the result of good conduct. For I have seen an individual
translation_text.mn136:12.4: here who refrained from killing living creatures … and had right view. And I saw that they were reborn in hell.’
translation_text.mn136:12.5: They say: ‘It seems that everyone who refrains from killing living creatures … and has right view is reborn in hell.
translation_text.mn136:12.6: Those whose notion is this have the right notion. Those whose notion is otherwise have a wrong notion.’
translation_text.mn136:12.7: And so they obstinately stick to what they have known, seen, and understood for themselves, insisting that: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’
translation_text.mn136:13.1: In this case, when an ascetic or brahmin says this:
translation_text.mn136:13.2: ‘It seems that there is such a thing as bad deeds, and the result of bad conduct,’ I grant them that.
translation_text.mn136:13.4: ‘I have seen an individual here who killed living creatures … and had wrong view. And after death, they were reborn in hell,’ I also grant them that.
translation_text.mn136:13.6: ‘It seems that everyone who kills living creatures … and has wrong view is reborn in hell,’ I don’t grant them that.
translation_text.mn136:13.8: ‘Those whose notion is this have the right notion. Those whose notion is otherwise have a wrong notion.’ I also don’t grant them that.
translation_text.mn136:13.9: And when they obstinately stick to what they have known, seen, and understood for themselves, insisting that: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile,’ I also don’t grant them that.
translation_text.mn136:13.11: Because the Realized One’s knowledge of the great analysis of deeds is otherwise.
translation_text.mn136:14.1: In this case, when an ascetic or brahmin says this:
translation_text.mn136:14.2: ‘It seems that there is no such thing as bad deeds, and the result of bad conduct,’ I don’t grant them that.
translation_text.mn136:14.4: ‘I have seen an individual here who killed living creatures … and had wrong view. And I saw that they were reborn in a heavenly realm,’ I grant them that.
translation_text.mn136:14.6: ‘It seems that everyone who kills living creatures … and has wrong view is reborn in a heavenly realm,’ I don’t grant them that. …
translation_text.mn136:14.11: Because the Realized One’s knowledge of the great analysis of deeds is otherwise.
translation_text.mn136:15.1: In this case, when an ascetic or brahmin says this:
translation_text.mn136:15.2: ‘It seems that there is such a thing as good deeds, and the result of good conduct,’ I grant them that.
translation_text.mn136:15.4: ‘I have seen an individual here who refrained from killing living creatures … and had right view. And I saw that they were reborn in a heavenly realm,’ I grant them that.
translation_text.mn136:15.6: ‘It seems that everyone who refrains from killing living creatures … and has right view is reborn in a heavenly realm,’ I don’t grant them that. …
translation_text.mn136:15.11: Because the Realized One’s knowledge of the great analysis of deeds is otherwise.
translation_text.mn136:16.1: In this case, when an ascetic or brahmin says this:
translation_text.mn136:16.2: ‘It seems that there is no such thing as good deeds, and the result of good conduct,’ I don’t grant them that.
translation_text.mn136:16.4: ‘I have seen an individual here who refrained from killing living creatures … and had right view. And after death, they were reborn in hell,’ I grant them that.
translation_text.mn136:16.6: ‘It seems that everyone who refrains from killing living creatures … and has right view is reborn in hell,’ I don’t grant them that.
translation_text.mn136:16.7: But when they say: ‘Those who know this are right.
translation_text.mn136:16.8: Those who know something else are wrong,’ I also don’t grant them that.
translation_text.mn136:16.9: And when they obstinately stick to what they have known, seen, and understood for themselves, insisting that: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile,’ I also don’t grant them that.
translation_text.mn136:16.11: Because the Realized One’s knowledge of the great analysis of deeds is otherwise.
translation_text.mn136:17.1: Now, Ānanda, take the case of the individual here who killed living creatures … and had wrong view, and who, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.mn136:17.2: That bad deed of theirs that is to be experienced as painful was either done previously, or later, or else at the time of death they undertook wrong view.
translation_text.mn136:17.3: And that’s why, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.mn136:17.4: But anyone here who kills living creatures … and has wrong view experiences the result of that in this very life, or in the next life, or in some subsequent period.
translation_text.mn136:18.1: Now, Ānanda, take the case of the individual here who killed living creatures … and had wrong view, and who is reborn in a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn136:18.2: That good deed of theirs that is to be experienced as pleasurable was either done previously, or later, or else at the time of death they undertook right view.
translation_text.mn136:18.3: And that’s why, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn136:18.4: But anyone here who kills living creatures … and has wrong view experiences the result of that in this very life, or in the next life, or in some subsequent period.
translation_text.mn136:19.1: Now, Ānanda, take the case of the individual here who refrained from killing living creatures … and had right view, and who is reborn in a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn136:19.2: That good deed of theirs that is to be experienced as pleasurable was either done previously, or later, or else at the time of death they undertook right view.
translation_text.mn136:19.3: And that’s why, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn136:19.4: But anyone here who refrains from killing living creatures … and has right view experiences the result of that in this very life, or in the next life, or in some subsequent period.
translation_text.mn136:20.1: Now, Ānanda, take the case of the individual here who refrained from killing living creatures … and had right view, and who is reborn in hell.
translation_text.mn136:20.2: That bad deed of theirs that is to be experienced as painful was either done previously, or later, or else at the time of death they undertook wrong view.
translation_text.mn136:20.3: And that’s why, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.mn136:20.4: But anyone here who refrains from killing living creatures … and has right view experiences the result of that in this very life, or in the next life, or in some subsequent period.
translation_text.mn136:21.1: So, Ānanda, there are deeds that are ineffective and appear ineffective. There are deeds that are ineffective but appear effective. There are deeds that are effective and appear effective. And there are deeds that are effective but appear ineffective.”
translation_text.mn136:21.2: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn136:21.3: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
